card.name: Dimension styles
card.desc: There are currently only two dimension styles - 45deg_diagonal_line and 45deg_arrow_line

card.name: Fonts
card.desc:
•	Blender can be used in Revit if we load a True type font onto our system (not currently loaded)
•	Blender can be used in Indesign if we load an open type font onto our system. (currently loaded)
•	 We cannot have the two simultaneously loaded as they have the same file name.  This issue may be able to be overcome (TBC)
•	There is a slight difference between Blender as seen in Indesign and blender as seen in Revit.   

•	The more significant problem is how Blender works with external parties.

•	Blender fonts cannot be read by anyone else who does not have these fonts loaded. This will affect anyone who receives our .RVT or .dwg files.
•	Revit will Blender default to a standard font in their system, however all layout and spacing will be destroyed. In short, all text will be be messed up.

•	There is no known work-around to prevent this issue.

•	Some people understand that there is a directive that Blender should only be used in competitions

card.name: Line Weights Table
card.desc: Lines between 1-9 on the table will change the weight of lines in relation to scale. Lines between 10-16 will remain consistent.

Determine which subcategories should stay and which should be deleted

data.text:
My suggestion here is:

1.	The “BVN” should be a prefix so we group all BVN line styles at the top of the list. If you open an existing project you’ll see that the list can get very long and it becomes harder and harder to find the BVN styles as they are all over the list depending on whether their names start with “dash”, “dot”, “fire” and “solid”.
2.	Thicknesses must not be in millimetres, remember the thicknesses change depending on view scale. There should be just a number to match the lineweight used by Revit instead.
3.	Line colour should be included in the name, even if the template only contains black lines. This way people can follow the convention without “getting creative” and putting the colour information anywhere they find fit.
4.	Line pattern variations shouldn’t be named “small”, “medium” or “large” as there will be other variations sitting in between those. Line pattern types should include dash size and space size or maybe just the dash size. E.g. Dash 3-2 (3mm dash and 2mm space) or simply Dash 3. For dotted lines the space size should be in the name. Note the space between the name and the numbers for clarity of read. (I never use spaces and try to stick to ANZRS as much as possible but in this case it reads much better with the space)
5.	Similar principle applies to colours as there can be variations of the same colour. E.g. Gray 128 or Green 000-128-064. This is another field where the space makes it read much clearer.
6.	The hierarchy of information should be:

[BVN prefix]_[two digit lineweight]_[linetype]_[colour]

Examples:
BVN_01_SOLID_BLACK
BVN_05_DOT 3.5_GREEN
BVN_04_DASH 3-2_GRAY 168

The lineweight could also be at the end so the styles are grouped by line pattern.
I used to use the standard convention below without issues.
[LINE STYLES.png](https://trello-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com/5773ce910d9f06e63aa4467e/5785ae57f8db2bab15d22151/08602a7bb0496fdf5bba86261a4cb382/LINE_STYLES.png)

Hey guys, can I please add a couple of suggestions based on project work experience?

1. The list below is from the current template. Can we please have the _BVN always at the end?
[TEXT STYLES.png](https://trello-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com/5773ce910d9f06e63aa4467e/577a07c2fc54eaa7c2bb0bf0/05de64fccdc818f5c98b87a6e4026c41/TEXT_STYLES.png) 

2. It would also be good to have the names show whether the style has transparent or opaque background too. For example, 2.5mm_BLACK_TRANSP_BVN or 2.5mm_BLACK_BOLD_OPAQUE_BVN. I can't speak for everyone but I'd say most projects (if not all of them) end up with transparent and opaque variations of those styles. That doesn't mean they should all be in the template but if at least the ones there come with the naming convention including "_TRANSP" users can create the variations using the same principle. Having said that, I would opt to have at least the 2.5mm text with both transparent and opaque options in the template.

data.text: Every new change in the template will be recorded in the 'RVT TEMPLATE CHANGE LOG' view under 'MODEL MANAGEMENT'
I always add a "_D" or "_M" so I can tell whether the hatch is a model or a drafting hatch. Maybe something to consider?

During schematic design we often need to show colourful diagrams like the below and it would be great to have the BVN standard colours setup as solid materials. We had to do that for ANU as needed them several times. I’d be happy to help as we setup a Revit Material Library just for those.

[Diagrams.jpg](https://trello-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com/5773ce910d9f06e63aa4467e/5773e09c438f98f824cc3375/bd7a68a4d4a7b72b8f2e409b519a8e33/Diagrams.jpg)

Hi guys, is it possible to add an underscore “_” to the beginning of the name of all views and schedule in the splashscreen and also the sheet name to make it easier to tell them apart from all the other views we have to delete when issuing models?

Hi guys, even though the idea of having pre-setup departments and colours in the Colour Scheme Manager is good, we cannot change names of pre-setup departments which makes them unusable. I don’t see how to get around that and make use of them in projects so I would either remove them all or call the colour scheme BVN COLOURS SAMPLE (or something like that).

card.name: Line Weights
card.desc: Line weights are inconsistent. For example, Doors have line weight 5 for projection and 6 for cut while Walls have line weight 3 for projection and 6 for cut. Also, Curtain Wall Mullions have line weight 5 and 6 (for projection and cut respectively).

data.text: Having all of the preloaded Sun Studies for the Solstices and Equinox times as views that can be quickly cropped using a scope box and placed onto sheets will really help in DA submissions.

@joe_banks ok great - thanks - ill have a look and think of any health specific ones that might be useful. Yes would have saved lots of time if NBH families had these already. When I started there seemed to be a bit of a divide between what DT and the project teams thought about the requirement for subcategories. I think they are very useful but again should be kept to a minimum. Also our joinery families in particular have lots of nested parts so can be a pain to subcategorise.

@bellapescia the standards are here - \\dc2-file001\Practice\InfoTech\BIM\Revit\RevitStandardsMasterBVN\02_BVN_Library\Standards
Standard ANZRS - Subcatagories.xlsx
we have added a few for specific functionality but tried to stick with ANZRS as best we could, are there any Health specific functionality you need, please let us know.

I should add that DT has made a massive effort to update all the subcategories and put every family on an appropriate one. we are at about 85% of the Library now that has been checked (excluding detail components, we haven't started those yet). shame that wasn't done before NBH.

card.name: What needs to be in a template and what needs to be outside of the template?

data.text: In terms of documentation standard items such as text styles, dim styles, object styles, arrowheads etc I think there definitely needs to be LESS in the Revit templates. Having so many options defeats the whole purpose of having the template in the first place and results in just as much inconsistency.
I think the BVN alphabet has been extremely useful on our job just for the filtering of view references alone - maybe this could be done another way but seems to work well on a large scale job.

Definitely needs some review along with subcategories and linestyles.
This is just my opinion but I think that because we work in 3D it is best to have very minimal variances in object styles and almost avoid dashed linestyles alltogether (apart from the obvious ones) - if the subcategories are set up properly view templates/settings are a better way to control appearances etc.

definitely need this. 
hardly any families were subcategorised for NBH and i spent some time doing this - there was no list I could follow (well not that i knew of?) and when we eventually did a reload of all families into some files there were some major unexpected graphic changes because object styles were not set up properly either.

On a job like NBH which has 15 different main architectural files we have difficulty maintaining all the legends between the files. One way to solve this was by making generic annotation families and loading this in - this way edits only need to be made once and there is more consistency. Perhaps if we had a set of these generic annotation legend families these could easily be standardised and used on multiple projects as suggested by Scott below?
The only issue is that legend components cant be used in a generic annotation family.

data.text: @davidbrown53 2 types are possible. We already have a 'Drawing level_BVN' and 'Drawing level_BVN 2' in the template

i thin we now have a decent group of past legends from recent projects that worked well- is there a way to save these for other teams to use if they wish? ie. partition legends, cover sheets with notes/ abbreviations, etc?

Could we simply have a recommended BVN short cut file that people can use if needed, and if others want, they can customise to suit their style? Everybody seems to have a different way of driving Revit....

Joe- I've reviewed the Documentation Guide and it doesn't mention this. I'd initially suggest you're right, UPPERCASE would be the default, and most people do hand drawn details with upper case text too, so once we agree, it should be consistent.

card.name: The best way to train Revit template & CART? (DT Induction, QA, ..)

data.text: CART has typically been done for staff on their induction day, however with large fluctuations of staff it gets hard. We're looking at sending a summary presentation of the CART slides after all the sessions tomorrow as a reminder/ reference of the material for people who have attended. it's sometimes hard to have is as a handbook or guide- comments really help during the presentation. It would be good to have an electronic 'placemat' similar to the QA one somewhere easy to find. it could have templates, CART, documentation guide, etc....?

agree with PW comments regarding the LEVEL with no RLs. I think the default for staff is to add levels to everything with RLs everywhere, when really it's not required, a simple LEVEL alone would suffice...

agree- labelling using something intuitive and practical would be good. Also, with the filters, it would be good if the level of detail shown somehow reflected CART ie. 1:500 sections would typically show a lot less detail for finishes, components, etc, compared to a 1:50 section showing more detail, etc.While something might already reflect this, we still see quite a few 1:500 sections with wall tile patterns, joinery, etc in minute detail....might be user error....

data.text:
I generally add a couple of AutoCAD Export configurations to every model

ACAD2010 (Project Internal)
ACAD2010 (Shared Coordinates)

I generally use ACAD 2010 as a baseline version, but this could probably move up now... I've been doing this since UTS because that was the request from the client... I doubt anyone is specifying this as the max release these days... but would probably keep it a couple of releases back (to be discussed)

There may be other configs that other people use regularly that could be included

I generally set solids to ACIS by default, so there may be an argument for also adding configs for Polymesh if anyone uses those...?

card.name: Are we going to create our template in 2017 (which has got some cool features such as view depth & text editor)?

data.text: Absolutely, but while there are new features in the new versions anything that could be in the previous versions should be added to those templates too.

card.name: Add Plot Configurations for standard Outputs

data.text:
I have to do this in every new file and it is always the same... Also users tend to create their own with irrelevant names I see them regularly created as 
A3 1-200 reduction
A3 
The scale of the output is uirrelevant to the print configuration

The relevant print sets are something along the lines of 

A1 Landscape 100%
A3 Landscape 100%
A3 Landscape 50%
A3 Landscape Fit to Page
A4 Landscape Fit to Page

data.text:
Even just having a placeholder set with a single sheet in each will set the precedent for how people should follow on with naming of print sets
A Series - Introduction
B Series - General Arrangement
C Series - Elevations
etc...

Users can then add sheets to the sets in the file.

data.text: @paulwintour there are some minutes posted on Slack channel #content-management regarding maintaining multiple versions of the library.

Yes that is the same philosophy. Control in terms of being able to query for the differences between the master and copies is important here. Jan's Family reporter addin comes in handy there. As for shared parameters, we could batch script a mass dump of the information across many project files.

@andrewmehr if we have views from sun, no shadows will be visible. If we are just creating a generic 3d view with shadows turned on, this is probably better done by setting up the sun settings in the template as opposed to pre-creating views.

a parallel would be that all families must exist in the BVN library. Some project families should migrate to the BVN standard but we give teams the flexibility to create project specific families. The same should be true for shared parameters.
@petahawkins isn't a lot of this stuff redundant if we use eTransmit?
A text diff (compare) tool could be used to highlight the differences between these and the master copy.

@paulwintour Good question. Obviously there needs to be a master copy for project startup but it might be a good idea to allow projects to amend their own copy and we regularly collect these and assess what new parameters should be merged into the master copy. A script to collate all the shared parameter files based on what's currently referenced in the active Revit projects could help here.
@petahawkins how can this be enforced?

@joe_banks It is common practice that all documentation is in capitals but we can get clarification from Scott H or Craig Burns on this. A competition maybe an exception. But in any case, we have a combination of both. It needs to be one or the other. The majority are upper case and it would appear the CART document promotes uppercase. Of course we can use the view on sheet parameter but this just adds extra complication and room for error
@joe_banks most projects start out as a competition when we have no idea what a door will end up becoming. All I am asking is one, simple conceptual door. We only need 1 size.

@paulwintour 
https://bvn.bloomfire.com/posts/1065204-model-issue-guidelines

I agree that there should be a BVN standard for revisioning. However we are often put in a position where we are to adhere with our client's numbering and revisioning system.  So it needs to be flexible to a certain degreee. Notwithstanding this, the need for the standard would assist us greatly in our arguments when we are refuting why we should not follow a poorly thought-out system.
@petahawkins can you post the Bloomfire link please.
View templates for sketches is very annoying.
The T&Cs is one thing. I'm mainly referring to the list of BVN commandments about do not rename worksets, do not ... This surely can be dropped off.

@davidbrown53 

There are guide notes on bloom fire about model issue requirements. This should be a non-negotiable, as it is a core element of the QA process.

E data Ts and C should be referenced on the splash screen only. Thge project should be publishing a copy of the T&Cs for all electronic data ( i.e dwgs and PDFs) and as such it should be issued on Aconex (or similar)  and referenced. Then if it needs to be updated, it is updated in one location only.
@andrewmehr what would be the difference between a shadow and a solar study? It is the same thing isn't?

card.name: Do we need more than one template?(eg. one for conceptual design, one for resi documentation, etc)

data.text: @davidbrown53 I don't believe this was ever official published was it? For a long time it was in a DO NOT USE phase. And also, when we have asked DT in the past to setup projects for competitions the main template was used.
sub-category standard document published as a BVN document in an accessible location.
@davidbrown53 its about our methodology. What's the benefit of keeping it central?

Hi Paul, is this an 'access issue' primarily or a methodology? We did have project specific shared parameter files [NBH still has one] but generally it caused issues...such as duplication of parameter naming, or the project would have 2 or more SP files. Happy to hear other peoples views
When issuing models etc, I believe the model issue revision notes are being followed, but it's really a case by case scenario and how diligent the person issuing the model.

@paulwintour  LEVEL 02/03 issue - you are right. 
needs to be fixed.
Do we need to create some line-based detail component families?
We try to standardise shortcuts a while ago, but the feedback was negative and people liked the idea of creating there own, or using the shortcuts they have built up over time
Do we need to change all of the fonts to Blender?

card.name: Do we need more than one template?(eg. one for conceptual design, one for resi documentation, etc)

data.text: At the moment in Revit 2016 we have two templates, BVN and Competition, has everyone looked at the Competition Template?
@paulwintour I agree, but I'd recommend to check Ian K first

card.name: Strategy for international work especially with NYC, discussion as to if an international or US template is need?

data.text: Is CAPITALS a standard? no really is it? we have lots of projects with all the view names in Title Case.

Totally agree with Paul, have had some issues trying to consensus on this in the Brisbane office, we have no defined standard.
even with what terminology means e.g. does "CD" mean concept design or Contract documentation? I have heard both used in both offices.

there are also implication for Newforma and Aconnex as they can see Issue P1 as being latter in the sequence than Issue A however it is issued with an earlier date. (it's never easy is it).

to confirm there is no document protocol for naming of filters. :frowning: 
Lets make one. :smile:

This defiantly need some review, it's a bit of a time consuming job.
ideally you to set up a test project, that has a few objects of every category, both in projection and cut. and views at all typical scales. print them out and check that the line styles and weights align to our expected standard.
edit and repeat and until we are happy.

I think this also has a big issue associated that is we need to define a standard for line-types and thickness and how they are named.

we also need to find a way to ensure all our content has matching object styles with the project template (HELP PROGRAMMERS?)

card.name: Do we need more than one template?(eg. one for conceptual design, one for resi documentation, etc)

data.text:
I would go with the second option of one more flexible template.
this also ties in with having a super lean template that just has the system families you need to start and your graphic standards.

unfortunately not all of these setting transfer with "transfer project standards" like Grid/ Level heads and a heap of other stuff.

this functionality can be extended by having sample files for system families  that are broken down by typology.
residential Walls Sample File
Commercial Tower walls Sample file
Floors
Roofs
Stairs
Railing etc.

card.name: Are we going to create our template in 2017 (which has got some cool features such as view depth & text editor)?

data.text:
yes we will, we have templates for 2014/2015/2016 right now and will continue this practice.
as for the view depth being cool, well, IMO. I'm not really a fan, just looks like the building is in fog. and raster print only.

We discussed this issue at a meeting on Friday and agreed to Archive 2014/2015 librarys (still accessible and supported but no longer developed).
all new families to be made in 2016.
this is both to reduce the wait time you mentioned and to take advantage of the new feature in the new family editor.
ordering of parameters, tools tips etc. 

The templates themselves are already available in 2015 and 2016 format.
\\dc2-file001\Practice\InfoTech\BIM\Revit\RevitStandards2016
this has both
02_FamilyTemplates (the BVN altered Templates)
04_OOTB Family Templates (out of the Box Templates)

Ultimately there is a bigger question here.
should there be any families other than system families loaded into the template? I would argue no but that is a conversation debate for another medium.

I have intentionally removed all doors and windows from the template.
it is not hard to load a door from the library and to select the types appropriate for the project.
conversely it can be quite time consuming to swap out inappropriate doors or windows when it requires them to be individually checked for positioning.

windows are probably the worst offender here and there is a lot more work that needs to go into how we handle windows at BVN. they have the potential to kill file performance more than any other type of element (depending on project typology) and some thought needs to go into selecting the appropriate types for each building.
happy to explain/demonstrate in detail.

card.name: Do we need more than one template?(eg. one for conceptual design, one for resi documentation, etc)

data.text: At HOK it was broken down into Architecture, Interior and Urban Design. Another solution is to just have a competition template, since that is how most projects start, and then later, use transfer project standards to copy info across. Or alternatively, we have our main template becomes more flexible (so no view templates or filters pre-applied to view, conceptual familes pre-loaded, etc).

card.name: Are we going to create our template in 2017 (which has got some cool features such as view depth & text editor)?

data.text: Yes I think we should multiple templates for the different versions we have running. So when I open up Revit 2017 is should be pointing to a Revit 2017 template.

At HOK we had multiple libraries. One for Revit 2015, one for Revit 2016, etc. A batch file upgrade was then run. Most of our templates are very old from Revit 2014. I understand that this is the most backward compatible way, but every time someone opens a family template they have to wait a few seconds which adds up.

What is the naming protocol for naming filters? I can't see it documented anywhere. This is why I think CART should be aligned with our Revit template. 

From our template, it looks as though it is numbered sequentially. Working with Tim C I know that he likes to keep things grouped. I previously prefixed it with the View Type, ("R" - 3D or "B" - Floors) . Generally it is a bit of a free for all which is why I created the deleted unused filters node in Dynamo.

I think we can get rid of the list of Dos and DONTs on the splash screen. This would be better located in the CART or BIM management plan. No one follows them and no one reads them (not that I condone this).

When syncing does anyone fill out details about what has changed? Is this a waste of time or useful? If we think it is valuable, can it be linked to the splashscreen (maybe as mentioned below)?
Unless we have a competition template, can we turn off the view templates in the views as it is much less flexible when starting a new project.
Legends are designed to go on sheets so can we make the view in CAPITALS to be consistent with the rest of the documentation
Can we ensure we have at least one basic window and door is loaded into the template

I think we should have a discussion about the shared parameter file. Most of the other large firms (that I am aware of), such as HOK, have a central SP file which is copied and pasted to create a project SP file. This way we don't have to keep asking DT to modify the file. I know that Mitch was against this but it would be good to hear other peoples thoughts.
When creating a new level, it should be LEVEL 02, not LEVEL 03. It looks as though some one deleted Level 02 when creating the template so it automatically goes to Level 03
Default text should be 2.5mm not schedule text

It would be good to have greater clarity over the revision sequencing for different phases. For example, p1, p2, … vs A, B, C vs 1,2,3. I’ve had SO many long discussions with principles who don’t understand this and why it’s important and it’s not clearly documented or understood.

Cascading levels of detail – I see ALL THE TIME people not understanding how to create views in Revit so that there is a one-way referencing system. There is a difference to duplicating a view as opposed to having a dependant view or a callout. People don’t think about this and you end up with either multiple elevation/section tags or drawings not cross referenced.  An example of this is scoping drawings or tiled sections. We need a strategy around this - either a filter to hide parent views (or un-referenced) or some other method.

our template and CART document should be alight to clarify when to use keynotes vs tags vs text. The codes in our documentation manual has both elements AND materials. This should be separated out into 2 lists. Elements should have tags. Materials are probably better as keynotes. Text should be avoided as it needs to be  manually updated.

Create a dedicated line style and view which has the OS grid/ MGA etc on it with Northing and Eastings. So 0,0, 500,0, 1000,0 etc. This way if the shared coordinates get messed-up it will be EASILY visible. Just having a known ‘point’ and ensuring this doesn’t change is more difficult because it often isn’t a round number so it requires more careful checking so a greater chance of error. 

We may also want to discuss the policy if checking out the workset (so admin rights) to prevent team members messing with it. We should also have separate coordinate families which show only Northing or only Easting as per a survey (so not both).

Currently our template is in meters to one decimal place. Every time I need I start a project I need to change it and most people don’t know how to do this so they just accept it. Our general arrangement legend says that levels are in meters which is fine. It doesn't need to be in mm. But if so, them meters hould be to 2 decimal places.

We should also have 2 types – one for levels setout and another indicating just the name without an RL for all other drawings. Tis is to avoid having to update multiple drawings with revision clouds when levels change. This is a result of the CART process and Scott Hardcastle/ Kevin Murphy can explain more.
Create a ‘Coordination’ Design stage with views of each workset in isolation

Solar study for winter solstice should be from 9-3pm to align with SEPP65. This should be applied to all studies (single, multi, etc).

We also have a Dynamo script which creates views from the sun. It would be good to have these views already in the Revit template as they are valuable for all project typologies, not just residential.

Views not named correctly in the following categories:

·         F – Floor, wall, ceilings
·         L - Furniture
·         H – Cores, stairs & lifts
·         R-Misc
·         U – Demo
·         V – Concrete
·         Working

All views, schedule and sheets should be in capitals as this is our documentation standard.

data.text:
That's great @andrewmehr ... That actually ticks a number of boxes in one go!

Thanks
@ian_james off course, I usually use a sheet with a "special titleblock" that reports many project parameters including: project info, revisions, key plan, ....
This may require some discussion / explanation, but is another excellent solution brought back from RTC

Can we set up the Splash Screen as a Sheet so that we can host other views on it...?
Schedules
Audit Views etc...
I have more info on this we can discuss at some point that I brought back from RTC as well as some other ideas.
A thought I had was that the Revision on this Sheet could be the issue revision and issue history of the model. We would need to regiment how we distinguish between sheet revisions and model revisions.

cards.name: Browser organisation

cards.desc: Line weights are inconsistent. For example, Doors have line weight 5 for projection and 6 for cut while Walls have line weight 3 for projection and 6 for cut. Also, Curtain Wall Mullions have line weight 5 and 6 (for projection and cut respectively).
cards.name: Line Weights

cards.desc: There are currently only two dimension styles - 45deg_diagonal_line and 45deg_arrow_line
cards.name: Dimension styles

cards.desc:
•	Blender can be used in Revit if we load a True type font onto our system (not currently loaded)
•	Blender can be used in Indesign if we load an open type font onto our system. (currently loaded)
•	 We cannot have the two simultaneously loaded as they have the same file name.  This issue may be able to be overcome (TBC)
•	There is a slight difference between Blender as seen in Indesign and blender as seen in Revit.   

•	The more significant problem is how Blender works with external parties.

•	Blender fonts cannot be read by anyone else who does not have these fonts loaded. This will affect anyone who receives our .RVT or .dwg files.
•	Revit will Blender default to a standard font in their system, however all layout and spacing will be destroyed. In short, all text will be be messed up.

•	There is no known work-around to prevent this issue.

•	Some people understand that there is a directive that Blender should only be used in competitions
cards.name: Fonts

cards.desc: Lines between 1-9 on the table will change the weight of lines in relation to scale. Lines between 10-16 will remain consistent.
cards.name: Line Weights Table
